instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Came in from the shit pile no know history.
seen some liquid on the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area (cleaned it)


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.58v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.57v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.58v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.58v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 18.36v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 18.9v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.428v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.321v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> 0.0005v

<SIGNAL>P5VSUS_EN</SIGNAL> 4.9v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.0003v <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR> 98.2KOHM
<RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR> pin 1 3.320v pin 2 0.003v (0.697 DIODE AND 98,2KOHM)
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>    (0.501 diode and 4.51 Mohm)

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.321v

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.392V
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.428V


BTW REAL CHARGER 85W
green light turns to orange after a while

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Battery is charging?
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> goes high when connect battery?
I only saw this issue with incorrect charger...
Bad SMC can cause it too.

In this case, check first <RESISTOR>R5040</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR> area; if charger is OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> 0.0005v
<SIGNAL>P5VSUS_EN</SIGNAL> 4.9v


That seems like a pretty obvious problem.....How can enable be 4.9V when it all runs from a 3.3V source?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Because there is a mosfet open? 
And letting 5v true

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7842</TRANSISTOR> would be the only suspect here.
